member.name: T:Spring.Objects.Factory.ObjectFactoryUtils
member.summary: Convenience methods operating on object factories, returning object instances, names, or counts.

remarks.p: The nesting hierarchy of an object factory is taken into account by the various methods exposed by this class.

member.author: Rod Johnson
Juergen Hoeller
Rick Evans (.NET)

member.name: F:Spring.Objects.Factory.ObjectFactoryUtils.FactoryObjectPrefix
member.summary: Used to dereference an and distinguish it from managed objects created by the factory.

remarks.p: For example, if the managed object identified as foo is a factory, getting &foo will return the factory, not the instance returned by the factory.

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.Factory.ObjectFactoryUtils.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class.

remarks.p: This is a utility class, and as such has no publicly visible constructors.

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.Factory.ObjectFactoryUtils.CountObjectsIncludingAncestors(Spring.Objects.Factory.IListableObjectFactory)
member.summary: Count all object definitions in any hierarchy in which this factory participates.

remarks.p: Includes counts of ancestor object factories.
Objects that are "overridden" (specified in a descendant factory with the same name) are counted only once.

member.param: The object factory.
member.returns: The count of objects including those defined in ancestor factories.

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.Factory.ObjectFactoryUtils.ObjectNamesIncludingAncestors(Spring.Objects.Factory.IListableObjectFactory)
member.summary: Return all object names in the factory, including ancestor factories.
member.param: The object factory.
member.returns: The array of object names, or an empty array if none.

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.Factory.ObjectFactoryUtils.ObjectNamesForTypeIncludingAncestors(Spring.Objects.Factory.IListableObjectFactory,System.Type)
member.summary: Get all object names for the given type, including those defined in ancestor factories.

remarks.p: Will return unique names in case of overridden object definitions.
Does consider objects created by s, or rather it considers the type of objects created by (which means that s will be instantiated).

member.param:
If this isn't also an , this method will return the same as it's own
method.
The that objects must match.
member.returns: The array of object names, or an empty array if none.

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.Factory.ObjectFactoryUtils.ObjectsOfTypeIncludingAncestors(Spring.Objects.Factory.IListableObjectFactory,System.Type,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Return all objects of the given type or subtypes, also picking up objects defined in ancestor object factories if the current object factory is an .

remarks.p: The return list will only contain objects of this type. Useful convenience method when we don't care about object names.

member.param: The object factory.
The of object to match.
Whether to include prototype objects too or just singletons (also applies to instances).
Whether to include instances too or just normal objects.
member.exception: If the objects could not be created.
member.returns: The of object instances, or an empty if none.

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.Factory.ObjectFactoryUtils.ObjectOfTypeIncludingAncestors(Spring.Objects.Factory.IListableObjectFactory,System.Type,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Return a single object of the given type or subtypes, also picking up objects defined in ancestor object factories if the current object factory is an .

remarks.p: Useful convenience method when we expect a single object and don't care about the object name.

member.param: The object factory.
The of object to match.
Whether to include prototype objects too or just singletons (also applies to instances).
Whether to include instances too or just normal objects.
member.exception: If the object could not be created.
If more than one instance of an object was found.
member.returns: A single object of the given type or subtypes.

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.Factory.ObjectFactoryUtils.ObjectOfType(Spring.Objects.Factory.IListableObjectFactory,System.Type,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Return a single object of the given type or subtypes, not looking in ancestor factories.

remarks.p: Useful convenience method when we expect a single object and don't care about the object name.

member.param: The object factory.
The of object to match.
Whether to include prototype objects too or just singletons (also applies to instances).
Whether to include instances too or just normal objects.
member.exception: If the object could not be created.
If not exactly one instance of an object was found.
member.returns: A single object of the given type or subtypes.

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.Factory.ObjectFactoryUtils.ObjectOfType(Spring.Objects.Factory.IListableObjectFactory,System.Type)

member.name: T:Spring.Objects.Navigation.NavigationExpression

member.name: T:Spring.Objects.Navigation.ObjectNavigator
member.summary: Utility class that enables easy object navigation.

remarks.p: This class allows users to get or set properties, as well as execute methods by navigating object graph using simple string expressions.
Object navigator can properly navigate not only simply objects, but also collections, lists, dictionaries, etc.

member.author: Aleksandar Seovic

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.Navigation.ObjectNavigator.GetValue(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Navigates root object using specified expression and returns value of the last expression node.
member.param: Root object.
Expression to evaluate.
member.returns: Value of the last node in the expression.

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.Navigation.ObjectNavigator.GetValue(System.Object,Spring.Objects.Navigation.NavigationExpression)
member.summary: Navigates root object using specified expression and returns value of the last expression node.

remarks.p: This version of the GetValue method uses parsed expression for evaluation, which can result in significant performance improvements as it avoids expression parsing and node resolution every time it is called.
If you plan to reuse same expression many times you should prepare parsed expression once and then use this method to evaluate it.

member.param: Root object.
Expression to evaluate.
member.returns: Value of the last node in the expression.

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.Navigation.ObjectNavigator.SetValue(System.Object,System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Navigates root object using specified expression and returns value of the last expression node.
member.param: Root object.
Expression to evaluate.
Value to set last node to.

If you plan to reuse same expression many times you should prepare parsed expression once and then use this method to evaluate it.

member.name: T:Spring.Objects.Support.AutoWiringEventHandlerValue.AutoWirer
member.summary: Performs the matching up of handler methods to one or more source events.

remarks.p: This class merely marshals the matching of handler methods to the events exposed by an event source, and then delegates to a concrete implementation (such as or ) to do the heavy lifting of actually wiring a handler method to an event.
Note : the order in which handler's are wired up to events is non-deterministic.

member.name: T:Spring.Objects.Support.MethodParametersCriteria

remarks.p: Handles conversion from an XML formatted string to a object (see below for an example of the expected XML format).
This converter must be registered before it will be available. Standard converters in this namespace are automatically registered by the class.

example.p: Find below some examples of the XML formatted strings that this converter will sucessfully convert. Note that the name of the top level (document) element is quite arbitrary... it is only the content that matters (and which must be in the format <add key="..." value="..."/>. For your continued sanity though, you may wish to standardize on the top level name of 'dictionary' (although you are of course free to not do so).
The following example uses a different top level (document) element name, but is equivalent to the first example.

member.name: T:Spring.Objects.TypeConverters.StringArrayConverter
member.summary: Converts a separated to a array.

remarks.p: Defaults to the list separator value of the current , so in the case of a different culture a different separator will be used (for example, the French ('fr-FR') culture uses the ';' (semi-colon) string as a list separator. Always consult the documentation for a specific locale to determine what list separator will be used. The default separator in the US and UK cultures is the ',' (comma) string.

If you want to provide your own, non-culture-specific list separator, you can set the value of the
property to the value that you want. Please note that this value will be used for all future conversions in preference to the culture-specific list separator.
Please note that the individual elements of a string will be passed through as is (i.e. no conversion or trimming of surrounding whitespace will be performed).
This should be automatically registered with any implementations.

example.p: Please note that this example assumes that the current culture uses the ',' string (i.e. the US or UK culture list separator).

member.name: T:Spring.Objects.IObjectWrapper
member.summary: The central interface of Spring.NET's low-level object infrastructure.

remarks.p: Typically not directly used by application code but rather implicitly via an .
Implementing classes have the ability to get and set property values (individually or in bulk), get property descriptors and query the readability and writability of properties.
This interface supports nested properties enabling the setting of properties on subproperties to an unlimited depth.
If a property update causes an exception, a will be thrown. Bulk updates continue after exceptions are encountered, throwing an exception wrapping all exceptions encountered during the update.
implementations can be used repeatedly, with their "target" or wrapped object changed.

member.author: Rod Johnson
Mark Pollack (.NET)

member.summary: Set a property value.

p.b: This is the preferred way to update an individual property.

member.param: The new property value.

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.IObjectWrapper.SetPropertyValue(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Set a property value.

remarks.p:
This method is provided for convenience only. The
method is more powerful.

member.param: The name of the property to set value of.
The new property value.

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.IObjectWrapper.SetPropertyValues(Spring.Objects.IPropertyValues)
member.summary: Set a number of property values in bulk.

remarks.p: This is the preferred way to perform a bulk update.

Note that performing a bulk update differs from performing a single update, in that an implementation of this class will continue to update properties if a recoverable error (such as a vetoed property change or a type mismatch, but not an invalid property name or the like) is encountered, throwing a containing all the individual errors. This exception can be examined later to see all binding errors. Properties that were successfully updated stay changed.

Does not allow the setting of unknown fields. Equivalent to
with an argument of false for the second parameter.

member.param: The collection of instances to set on the wrapped object.

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.IObjectWrapper.SetPropertyValues(Spring.Objects.IPropertyValues,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set a number of property values in bulk with full control over behavior.

remarks.p: Note that performing a bulk update differs from performing a single update, in that an implementation of this class will continue to update properties if a recoverable error (such as a vetoed property change or a type mismatch, but not an invalid property name or the like) is encountered, throwing a containing all the individual errors. This exception can be examined later to see all binding errors. Properties that were successfully updated stay changed.
Does not allow the setting of unknown fields.

member.param: The to set on the target object
Should we ignore unknown values (not found in the object!?)

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.ObjectUtils.IsAssignableAndNotTransparentProxy(System.Type,System.Object)
member.summary: Checks whether the supplied is not a transparent proxy and is assignable to the supplied .

remarks.p: Neccessary when dealing with server-activated remote objects, because the object is of the type TransparentProxy and regular is testing for assignable types does not work.
Transparent proxy instances always return when tested with the 'is' operator (C#). This method only checks if the object is assignable to the type if it is not a transparent proxy.

member.param: The target to be checked.
The value that should be assigned to the type.
member.returns: if the supplied is not a transparent proxy and is assignable to the supplied .

member.name: M:Spring.Objects.ObjectUtils.IsAssignable(System.Type,System.Object)
member.summary: Determine if the given is assignable from the given value, assuming setting by reflection.

remarks.p: Considers primitive wrapper classes as assignable to the corresponding primitive types.
For example used in an object factory's constructor resolution.

member.param: The target .
The value that should be assigned to the type.
member.returns: True if the type is assignable from the value.

If you require special resolution, do not use this method, but rather instantiate your own .

member.returns: A resolved instance.
member.exception: If the type cannot be resolved.

member.name: T:Spring.Objects.ObjectWrapper
member.summary: Default implementation of the interface that should be sufficient for all normal uses.

remarks.note: Auto-registers all default property converters (not the custom ones) in the namespace. Applications can call the instance's method to register a converter for the particular instance.
remarks.p: will convert and array values to the corresponding target arrays, if necessary. Custom s that deal with s or arrays can be written against a comma delimited as arrays are converted in such a format if the array itself is not assignable.

member.name: T:Spring.Pool.Support.ISync
member.summary: Acquire/Release protocol, base of many concurrency utilities.

remarks.p: objects isolate waiting and notification for particular logical states, resource availability, events, and the like that are shared across multiple threads.

Use of s sometimes (but by no means always) adds flexibility and efficiency compared to the use of plain .Net monitor methods and locking, and are sometimes (but by no means always) simpler to program with.
Used internally for implementation of a since the Semaphore API is still under review.

member.author: Doug Lea
Federico Spinazzi (.Net)

member.name: M:Spring.Pool.Support.ISync.Acquire
member.summary: Wait (possibly forever) until successful passage. Fail only upon interuption. Interruptions always result in `clean' failures. On failure, you can be sure that it has not been acquired, and that no corresponding release should be performed. Conversely, a normal return guarantees that the acquire was successful.

member.name: M:Spring.Pool.Support.ISync.Release
member.summary:
Potentially enable others to pass.
Because release does not raise exceptions, it can be used in `finally' clauses without requiring extra embedded try/catch blocks. But keep in mind that as with any java method, implementations may still throw unchecked exceptions such as Error or NullPointerException when faced with uncontinuable errors. However, these should normally only be caught by higher-level error handlers.

member.name: M:Spring.Pool.Support.ISync.Attempt(System.Int64)
member.summary:
Wait at most msecs to pass; report whether passed.
The method has best-effort semantics: The msecs bound cannot be guaranteed to be a precise upper bound on wait time in Java. Implementations generally can only attempt to return as soon as possible after the specified bound. Also, timers in Java do not stop during garbage collection, so timeouts can occur just because a GC intervened. So, msecs arguments should be used in a coarse-grained manner. Further, implementations cannot always guarantee that this method will return at all without blocking indefinitely when used in unintended ways. For example, deadlocks may be encountered when called in an unintended context.
member.param: the number of milleseconds to wait An argument less than or equal to zero means not to wait at all. However, this may still require access to a synchronization lock, which can impose unbounded delay if there is a lot of contention among threads.
member.returns: true if acquired

member.name: T:Spring.Pool.Support.Semaphore

summary.p: Base class for counting semaphores based on Semaphore implementation from Doug Lea.

member.remarks:
Conceptually, a semaphore maintains a set of permits. Each acquire() blocks if necessary until a permit is available, and then takes it.
Each release adds a permit. However, no actual permit objects are used; the Semaphore just keeps a count of the number available and acts accordingly.
A semaphore initialized to 1 can serve as a mutual exclusion lock.
Used internally for implementation of a since the Semaphore API is still under review.
member.author: Doug Lea
Federico Spinazzi (.Net)

member.name: F:Spring.Pool.Support.Semaphore.nPermits
member.summary: current number of available permits

summary.p: Create a Semaphore with the given initial number of permits.
Using a seed of 1 makes the semaphore act as a mutual exclusion lock.
Negative seeds are also allowed, in which case no acquires will proceed until the number of releases has pushed the number of permits past 0.

member.name: M:Spring.Pool.Support.Semaphore.Release
member.summary: Release a permit

member.name: M:Spring.Pool.Support.Semaphore.Acquire
member.summary: Acquire a permit

member.name: M:Spring.Pool.Support.Semaphore.Attempt(System.Int64)
member.summary: Wait at most msecs millisconds for a permit
member.param: number of ms to wait
member.returns: true if aquired

member.name: M:Spring.Pool.Support.Semaphore.Release(System.Int64)
member.exception: if n is negative.

member.name: T:Spring.Pool.IPoolableObjectFactory
member.summary: Defines lifecycle methods for objects that are to be used in an implementation.

remarks.p: The following methods summarize the contract between an and an an .

list.item: is called whenever a new instance is needed.
is invoked on every instance before it is returned from the pool.
is invoked on every instance when it is returned to the pool.
is invoked on every instance when it is being dropped from the pool (see

remarks.p: Based on the Jakarta Commons Pool API.

member.author: Federico Spinazzi

member.summary: Creates an instance that can be returned by the pool.
member.returns: An instance that can be returned by the pool.

member.name: M:Spring.Pool.IPoolableObjectFactory.DestroyObject(System.Object)
member.summary: Destroys an instance no longer needed by the pool.

remarks.p:
Invoked on every instance when it is being "dropped" from the pool (whether due to the return value from a call to the
method, or for reasons specific to the pool implementation.)

member.param: The instance to be destroyed.

member.name: M:Spring.Pool.IPoolableObjectFactory.ValidateObject(System.Object)
member.summary: Ensures that the instance is safe to be returned by the pool. Returns false if this object should be destroyed.

remarks.p: Invoked in an implementation-specific fashion to determine if an instance is still valid to be returned by the pool. It will only be invoked on an "activated" instance.

member.param: The instance to validate.
member.returns: if this object is not valid and should be dropped from the pool, otherwise .

member.name: M:Spring.Pool.IPoolableObjectFactory.ActivateObject(System.Object)
member.summary: Reinitialize an instance to be returned by the pool.

remarks.p: Invoked on every instance before it is returned from the pool.

member.param: The instance to be activated.

member.name: M:Spring.Pool.IPoolableObjectFactory.PassivateObject(System.Object)
member.summary: Uninitialize an instance to be returned to the pool.

member.name: P:Spring.Proxy.IProxyTypeBuilder.ClassAttributes
member.summary: The list of custom s that the proxy class must be decorated with.

remarks.p: Note that the list is composed of instances of the actual s that are to be applied, not the s of the s.

example.p: The following code snippets show examples of how to decorate the the proxied class with one or more s.

member.name: P:Spring.Proxy.IProxyTypeBuilder.MemberAttributes
member.summary: The custom s that the proxy members must be decorated with.

remarks.p: This dictionary must use simple s for keys (denoting the member names that the attributes are to be applied to), with the corresponding values being s.

The key may be wildcarded using the '*' character... if so, then those proxy members that match against the key will be decorated with the attendant list of s. This naturally implies that using the '*' character as a key will result in the attendant list of s being applied to every member of the proxied class.

example.p: The following code snippets show examples of how to decorate the members of a proxied class with one or more s.

member.name: M:Spring.Proxy.InheritanceProxyTypeBuilder.BuildProxy
member.summary: Creates a proxy that inherits the proxied object's class.

remarks.p: Only (non-final) methods can be proxied, unless they are members of one of the interfaces that target class implements. In that case, methods will be proxied using explicit interface implementation, which means that client code will have to cast the proxy to a specific interface in order to invoke the methods.

member.returns: The generated proxy class.

member.name: M:Spring.Util.ReflectionUtils.GetMostSpecificMethod(System.Reflection.MethodInfo,System.Type)
member.summary: Finds that method on the supplied that most closely matches the supplied . if there is one.

remarks.p: For example, the supplied may be IFoo.Bar() (i.e. the Bar() method from the IFoo interface), and the supplied may be the DefaultFoo class that just so happens to declare a Bar() method. This method will return the DefaultFoo.Bar() method because this method most closely matches the name and parameters of the supplied . This is useful because it enables attributes on that method to be found.

member.param: The method to be invoked, which may come from an interface.
The target for the current invocation. May be or may not even implement the method.
member.returns: The more specific method, or the original method if the doesn't specialize it or implement it, or is .
member.exception: If is .

member.name: M:Spring.Util.StringUtils.HasLength(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if a string has length.
member.param: The string to check, may be .
member.returns: if the string has length and is not .

example.code: StringUtils.HasLength(null) = false StringUtils.HasLength("") = false StringUtils.HasLength(" ") = true StringUtils.HasLength("Hello") = true

member.name: M:Spring.Util.StringUtils.HasText(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if a has text.

remarks.p: More specifically, returns if the string is not , it's is > zero (0), and it has at least one non-whitespace character.

member.param: The string to check, may be .
member.returns: if the is not , > zero (0), and does not consist solely of whitespace.

example.code: StringUtils.HasText(null) = false StringUtils.HasText("") = false StringUtils.HasText(" ") = false StringUtils.HasText("12345") = true StringUtils.HasText(" 12345 ") = true

member.name: M:Spring.Util.StringUtils.IsNullOrEmpty(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if a is or an empty string.

remarks.p: More specifically, returns if the string is , it's is equal to zero (0), or it is composed entirely of whitespace characters.

member.param: The string to check, may (obviously) be .
member.returns: if the is , has a length equal to zero (0), or is composed entirely of whitespace characters.

example.code: StringUtils.IsNullOrEmpty(null) = true StringUtils.IsNullOrEmpty("") = true StringUtils.IsNullOrEmpty(" ") = true StringUtils.IsNullOrEmpty("12345") = false StringUtils.IsNullOrEmpty(" 12345 ") = false

member.name: M:Spring.Util.TypeAliasResolver.Resolve(System.String)
member.summary: Resolves the supplied type name.
member.param: The supplied type name.
member.returns: If the supplied type name is an alias, the fully resolved type name is returned (). If no alias could be found that matches the supplied type name (or the supplied type name is or consists wholly of whitespace characters), then the type name will be returned as is.
